title: One is too many, a thousand will never be enough
transcript:
NARRATOR: While traveling in Bangkok, Wa LeHulere stopped to look at a stack of books being sold on the side of the street. He was sorting through the stack when he happened upon a curious looking folder of language tapes

KEMANG WA LEHULERE: I initially was very surprised if not shocked actually that they would be an American accent program. Just the idea of someone learning how to sound a particular way. I was thinking about this idea of mimicking something or the learning of, or acquiring a specific way of speaking.

KEMANG WA LEHULERE: While sitting with these tapes I began to reflect on language but also the act of speaking. There's a writer who is name Franz Ferdinand who said to speak is to support civilization. this line came into mind when I was thinking about these tapes and listening to them. I was really interested in teaching a parrot how to speak American. But that became really complicated when we started discussing bringing the parrot over, also I hadn't done much research properly, about what parrots were you know? Their behavior. it's only once I got one that I began studying and then I realized to that they're quite sensitive animals actually so I had to scrub the idea all together of having a living parrot as part of the work.

It's me thinking about the cultural impact of the United States of America in terms of an impact on South African society, so yeah it's me kind of meditating through a number of issues.
